comments.content: as usually, i always like your explanation...

WRONG! The patch panel to the walljack is WITHIN the cat5e specification. Now the problem here is the walljack to the room so why is placing a switch in the patch panel solve the issue????? do these guys really know what theyre talking about?
as usually, i always like your explanation...

discussion.content:
This is a very tricky one, so let me explained clearly: 
Place a switch at the hotel's patch panel for connecting each room's cables basically means placing a switch in each room's IDF.

comments.content:
I agree with you about D. 
Repeaters donâ€™t extend the maximum length of a single segment; they just enable you to tie two segments together. There is no point in placing the repeater between the patch panel and the room.

Wouldn't it make more sense to place a switch on the table? If placed at the wall jack, then wires to the table would be a mess on the floor. In most conference rooms I see a whole in the table with cables sticking out or a switch on the table. Either way, in the conference room, the cable(s) are run under the floor.

discussion.content:
A makes no sense. There will always be a switch at a patch panel. That's what patch panels are for, to connect points to switches. So A is a dumb answer. Placing the switches on the tables will just make a mess. I'm not sure about repeaters as I've never used them.
Placing a switch at the wall jack and running cables from the makes the most sense so I say D.

"The maximum length for a cable segment is 100 metres (330 ft) per TIA/EIA 568-5-A. If longer runs are required, the use of active hardware such as a repeater or switch is necessary."

So according to what guys below say, that patch panels are usually placed with or near switches, then a repeater would do the work. BUT repeater is a 2-port device.

I'd go with a switch at the patch panel.
Those saying that D is the answer clearly have not seen an actual network setup. LOL placing a switch at a wall jack yall killing me

"The contractor is concerned that the room will be out of specification if cables are run in each room from the wall jacks" Which wall jack are they talking about?
Most likely the Demarcation.
Because if you add the length of cable from conference room to Demarcation + demarcation to god know where can be out of specification. This is the reason you must place a repeater, switch to strengthen the signal.

After thinking about this for a long time, A is indeed correct
B and D are insecure places for placing switches, so we can rule those out.
While C does work, A is a simpler solution. Switches typically boost/regenerate signal, so putting in a switch at the patch panel will regenerate it enough that it'll last from the ISP modem -> patch panel -> wall jack -> table.
Typically in real world scenarios you would just use a repeater but, this part "each room in the conference center to allow wired Internet access going to individual tables." is why its A

It is simple. Just search in Google for Cat5e repeater devices. Example: "1-port Gigabit High-Power PoE+ Extender Repeater, is designed to extend connection distances from a PoE source to an output device another 100 m (328 ft.) via Cat5e or Cat6 cable. You can cover even longer distances by cascading these extenders on a network. More than one can be chained thus bringing distance even further. Devices are not expensive and in this scenario is the best option. Answer is C.

I thought C made the most sense, but I think I have figured out why A is the answer. The patch panel for the conference room is not the demarcation point for the internet service. There is an unknown length of unknown cable running from the Demarcation point (at the Main Distribution Frame?) to this patch panel. The question doesn't state this, but we COULD infer this from the scenario I suppose. So "upgrading" the patch panel by installing a single switch to boost the signal would be the simplest, cheapest, and most secure way to address the problem. 

for what it's worth I think questions like this are beyond unreasonable. It would take several minutes to sleuth your way through all that and even then, how do we know the patch panel doesn't already have a switch? So much of what makes this answer correct must be inferred or guessed, and you've only got about 60 seconds per question, so if you get one like this, it's almost more efficient to just guess.

comments.content: uuurrgghhh, switches don't boost signals....they direct traffic accordingly to Mac addresses. In this case, a switch in the panel makes sense because if tables or computer have to be moved around...all you gotta do is disconnect from the switch.

discussion.content: Unless the explanation is beyond the scope of the CompTIA Network + objectives, I don't see why the answer would not be D.

Answer should be C
A. normally patch panel is already near to switches. So doesn't make any difference.
B. Non-sense
D. Are you really going to install switches to each wall jacks? if there are 10 wall jacks you are going to install 10 switches behind the walls? - total nonsense

The answer should be C
Repeater will regenerate the signals so it will do the job.

comments.content: No Sir, one switch will do the job, you don't need to put switch to every jack, just configure the link from the patch panel to the jack and then to switch as a trunk link. D is correct answer

discussion.content: I believe answer should be D. The cable length from the patch panel to the wall jacks are within specification. If he is concerned that the room will be out of specification when he runs cables from the jacks to the tables then adding an additional switch at the patch panel would help nothing with the length constraints, the answer cannot be A.

Surely answer would be D?! How can boosting the signal from its source point increase the overall maximum distance? Makes no sense, would be more logical to place a switch at the wall jack and run cables from there. This would boost signal and allow for greater distance coverage?

The given Answer is correct FE80 is a dead wrong google patch panel then talk later.

Place the switch in non-secured area? 
I think C is better

discussion.content: I don't understand- how switch in the patch panel place will improve cat5e length concern? It doesn't add-up. Repeaters in between, switches on wall jacks on other hand would do the job. But from sysadmin point of view-to eliminate client-equipment unnecessary interaction- repeaters will be the best option. Correct me if I am wrong!

questions.question_text: A contractor is setting up and configuring conference rooms for a convention. The contractor sets up each room in the conference center to allow wired Internet access going to individual tables. The contractor measured the distance between the hotel's patch panel to the jack, and the distance is within Cat 5e specifications. The contractor is concerned that the room will be out of specification if cables are run in each room from the wall jacks. Which of the following actions should the contractor take to ensure the cable runs meet specifications and the network functions properly?

choices.A: Place a switch at the hotel's patch panel for connecting each room's cables
choices.D: place a switch at the wall jack and run the cables in the room from there
choices.C: Place repeaters between the patch panel and the rooms
choices.B: Place a switch on each table to ensure strong connectivity
